review:
[h1]Furtivité en parties rapides[/h1]
La furtivité est réduite à son plus simple concept, pour un petit jeu agréable à parties rapides.

[i]Par contre ce jeu nourrit une légende urbaine : Si les caméléons changent effectivement de couleurs, ça n'est pas pour les adapter à leur environnement. [b]Ils ont des couleurs très spécifiques en fonction de leur race et sexe et leurs couleurs changent en fonction de leur humeur ou état de santé.[/b]
(Si vous cherchez le roi du camouflage, il existe une variété de seiche qui fait ça super bien, mais c'est moins glamour.)[/i]

✅ Concept sympathique. Des éléments de gameplay plutôt originaux, mais uniquement par thématique de niveaux. 

⚠️ Les niveaux sont soit trop nombreux, soit pas assez variés. En tout cas il y a un problème de rythme. On enchaîne tout ça un peu trop mécaniquement et on finit par s'ennuyer un peu, malgré les défis.

⚠️ Les défis se limitent à la collecte d'objets et chrono. Assez basique pour motiver le joueur à rejouer les missions.

⚠️ Musiques assez fades. Pourtant pas mauvaises, mais elles ne se prêtent peut-être pas assez bien à l'action et au type de jeu.

review:
《Spy Chameleon》一款很考验操作和判断力的俯视角动作游戏，游戏主要利用颜色来做文章，玩家控制的变色龙需要时刻保持可周围环境的颜色一致，顺利躲过摄像头的捕捉，难度比较大的关卡对操作精度要求不低，有的时候实在是过于苛刻，对于没啥耐心地玩家来说简直是折磨。

[h1]游戏体验[/h1]
游戏早期的官桥难度还可以接受，但是后期的难度确实不低，对操作的精准度要求很高，稍有偏差便会被摄像头发现，或者被首位发现。不过游戏的难度梯度设置还算合理，当然难度大的关卡还是要尝试多变才行。游戏说是潜行游戏，实际上还是考验玩家的手眼协调能力。游戏中也设有不少收集要素和最佳时间挑战，追求完美游戏的玩家估计要受苦了。

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1870227625

[h1]总结[/h1]
总的来说是一款非常不错的小品级游戏，适合用来挑战和消磨时间吧。推荐给喜欢折磨自己的你来尝试，游戏每一关的通关方式都有很多，玩家可以尝试反复通关来找到最佳路线用时最少，可以和全球玩家pk用时。

[b]Pros[/b]
+60FPS
+Polished gameplay
+Easy to pick up and put down (do a few levels here and there)
+Excellent level & challenge progress tracking
+Good graphics
+Fun
+Great difficulty level (with option for hard mode)

[b]Cons[/b]

A well done and nicely thought out “stealth” puzzle game. 

Now, I put stealth in quotes because you don’t sneak around in the dark and hide when you get caught. You are a Chameleon, of course, and have to avoid touching the enemies line of sight while collecting flies (and ladybugs). Keeping in line with a Chameleon’s natural ability, you can change to one of 4 colors to match a colored square or paint spill. This helps you avoid detection. 

This game is pretty well polished. Levels are not too hard, but do present a challenge where you’ll have to think where and when to move. I’ll admit for 2-3 levels I had to check a YouTube video of someone trying it to make sure I was going about it correctly. There’s a few enemy types and you’re introduced to new concepts slowly and easily. Each level will have one or more checkpoints so you don’t have to start all over if you’re detected. A major plus to avoid frustration.

I used a 360 controller and the controls are responsive and tight. When mistakes were made it almost always felt like my fault.

review:
Aussi con de par principe que ne l'évoque son titre, RGB agent vous permet d'incarner un chameléon devant s'infiltrer dans les locaux ennemis afin d'effectuer telle ou telle mission (5 au total découpées via chapitre). Ainsi, si la trame annecdotique du "scénario" permet d'établir un background au jeu, c'est plus les propritées mécaniques et architecturale du jeu qui retiendrons votre attention.  Je sous entend ici le GD et le LD du jeu. Avis aux connaisseurs.

  Comme je le disais en amont, ce puzzle game vous permet d'apprendre l'adaptation du chameléon. Changeant de couleur ( Rouge , vert , bleu , jaune ) aux grès des environnements, vous devrez vous fondre dans le décors afin de rejoindre la sortie. 
 A cela rien de trop compliqué étant donné que le jeu est muni d'une bonne courbe de difficulté et n'est pas punitif au delà du raisonnable. Vous permettant de terminer le jeu en environ 6 h.    

Seulement voilà, il y a un problème : la répétitivité. Rien n'est parfait et à l'image de ce constat c'est même l'un des seuls défauts du jeu ( avec les pbl de collision ). L'ensemble étant pour moi de bonne facture. 

Pour en venir au coeur du problème, le soucis émane de la rejouabilité. Car oui, le titre devient chiant à la longue par manque de contenu.  Une fois un atelier fini, vous avez la possibilité de le refaire afin de remplir les deux objectifs  annexes ( contre la montre , collectibles ).  Puis, une fois le mode normal terminé, vous devrez refaire un par un ces ateliers ( en difficile) afin de gravir les 100 %... Enfin bon vous voyez le topo. 

Donc voilà, pour faire clair en dehors d'une rejouabilité mal pensée, ce puzzle game est pas assez sympa à faire. 
  Attention de ne pas en abuser .

author: {'steamid': '76561198040842672', 'num_games_owned': 3000, 'num_reviews': 192, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1501224998}
review:
Spy Chameleon - RGB Agent is a top-down stealth puzzle game. You play as chameleon secret agent who needs to make his way through 75 levels without being detected.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
Overall the game looks decent enough but the levels are bit boring visually and get quite repetitive after a while. The way the game displays vision cones can be problematic too and telling multiple overlapping vision cones apart is quite hard.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Sound effects and music are passable enough but nothing particularly memorable.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The game is structured like a typical casual puzzle game. You play through 75 levels split in 5 sets. Each level has three challenges: collect all 10 flies, beat the time limit and collect all the ladybugs (which only appear once you have completed the level once). In practice this means that you need to play through each level two or three times if you want to complete all the challenges.

The levels themselves contain various enemies and other hazards and every time you are detected you are returned to the previous checkpoint. Unfortunately the stealth mechanics in the game just are not very good. Your main tool as a chameleon is your ability to change color to blend in the background. Unfortunately the game does not do a very good job with this mechanic and it's useful only in specific areas.

The level and puzzle design are quite weak, too. The puzzles are extremely simple and the levels themselves don't have enough variety. The game is passably fun early on but starts feeling repetitive way too soon.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Overall the game isn't particularly difficult even on hard, although to be fair I only completed the Get All Flies challenge in most levels. Pretty much all the puzzles have obvious solutions and the only difficulty comes from levels that require precise timing.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The default keyboard controls are pretty bad and there does not seem to be a way to rebind keys. You can play with a mouse too, but this felt rather imprecise to me.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
There's no real story and very little writing.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
The game suffers from some annoying bugs and glitches. For starters, every time you launch the game it will reset to normal difficulty. This can be pretty annoying, especially if you going for the hard-only achievements.

The hit detection is pretty bad too, and the hit box for your character doesn't quite match the 3D model.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Spy Chameleon - RGB Agent is a fairly bad puzzle game. The level and puzzle design are rather weak and the stealth mechanics are poorly implemented. I wouldn't recommend the game, you are much better off playing something like Stealth Bastard Deluxe or Mark of the Ninja for your 2D stealth puzzle fix.

I played through the game on hard and completed the Get All Flies challenge in all the levels. This took me around 2.5 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022266051', 'num_games_owned': 3249, 'num_reviews': 183, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1487991692}
review:
[h1]I can't recommend a game to my friends that I myself got annoyed with and didn't finish the campaign.[/h1]

While the game is certainly well done and polished, the level design really got annoying requiring some rather precise timing and movement, and that just killed the fun for me.  I made it to about level 45 or so in the 1.4hrs I played before finally going [i]"ok, this is ridiculous.  I've had enough."[/i]  (the rest of my game time per Steam was idling)

[h1]The PROs:[/h1]
+ Polished
+ Nice graphics
+ Neat idea
+ Fun for awhile
+ Checkpoints on a level a definite plus

[h1]The EH:[/h1]
- Strategy?  I guess I didn't see much strategy required.  You see their movement pattern, and you do the obvious.  No analyzing the entire level to come up with any plan or path at all required on vast majority of levels.

[h1]The CONs:[/h1]
- Eventually requires very precise timing and movement.  That killed the fun factor for me.  This was my biggest gripe with the game.

- Level balance?   Not a smooth progression of difficulty.  Some levels seem way too easy, intermixed with levels that require much too precise timing for movements, back to a level that takes 10 secs to complete the first time you see it.

- To get the "3 stars" (Get All Flies, Speed, and Get All Ladybugs) you basically play the same level 3 times?   Um, no thanks.  Or I just missed something in how I was supposed to play this game.  The ladybugs don't unlock until you complete the level once, so you have to do each level at least twice minimum.  And getting all the flies usually meant you didn't get the time bonus either, so a 3rd run is usually required. (And this isn't a game where I want to play each level over and over.)

[h1]Overall:  It's well done, but... it's just not 'fun'. ymmv.   6 out of 10.  At best.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197970833215', 'num_games_owned': 1329, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1419134059}
review:
Spy Chameleon is a puzzle game where you are a chameleon who has five missions to conduct "spy-like" actions: take some pictures of a famous person, steal secrets, hack a computer system. Each mission has 14 levels leading up to that end of mission level. In each level you must stealthily make your way to the end collecting flies along the way. Once you reach the end, another play through will show some ladybugs, usually in hard to reach locations, that you can grab as a snack.

As a chameleon, you have the ability to change color to blend into your surroundings. Early on this isn't required, but later in the game, you will need to move from colored location to colored location avoiding the light cones of the guards. 

While the game is technically a puzzle game, if I had to classify it I would call it a top down platformer - if there is such a thing. In order to do more than burn through the level, i.e. speed run or grab the ladybugs, timing and color switching (by pressing buttons like you would jump with a platformer) with precision. I only played through the normal levels. The developers had to add a normal setting because too many people were complaining about the difficulty of the original (now called hard) default setting. 

Don't let the cartoony graphics fool you - this isn't a child's game. It may appeal to puzzle players (there is no penalty for getting caught other than the timer keeps going) and to platform players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022189669', 'num_games_owned': 1857, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1776, 'last_played': 1457517949}
review:
Spy Chameleon is an incredibly fun action puzzle game wherein you must reach the exit of a level by avoiding vision cones of enemies. It utilises interesting mechanics that I haven't seen in other games, such as the ability to blend into the environment to avoid detection, as a chameleon would do in real life.

[h1]Positives[/h1]

- A unique concept that really makes for an enjoyable game that you will keep coming back to.

- Beautiful graphics.

- In-game collectibles. Perhaps you've already beaten a level, but you can always go back and try to collect all of the hard-to-reach ladybugs!

- Trading cards and achievements. The achievements are well-paced, varying in difficulty. Unlike most games, there's no stupid achievements like playing for 40 hours or beating the time of 10 others on your friend list.

- An emphasis on speed. Each level has a challenge time to beat, and there's also an achievement for beating every level in under 18 minutes. That's no easy feat, and adds a real challenge to the game once you've already beaten every level.

- Cloud saving and controller support. You can stop playing on one computer, then start playing on another, with no loss of progress. You can plug a controller in mid-game and the game will automatically update to show you controller controls rather than keyboard controls.

- Global leaderboards for times. So you think you have a fast time? Check how you stack up globally!

[h1]Negatives[/h1]

- Some of the levels have ridiculously narrow margins of error regarding precise movement. For example, the final level has a vision cone that must be blocked by a filing cabinet to pass, though the cabinet is mere pixels wider than is required. Pushing the cabinet even slightly too far will mean you have to go back to the last checkpoint, essentially ruining a speedrun of that level.

- There's a few minor 'detection' glitches; you will occasionally get detected when you shouldn't, and occasionally fail to get detected when you should. This doesn't have any real impact on the game, as the difference either side is only a fraction of a second.

- In addition to beating the challenge time on each level, the gamer is also prompted to beat a much faster time shown when starting Speedrun mode. I can only assume these are developer suggestion times for the 'Sprinter' achievement. While it's nice that they gave suggestions, many of the times are literally impossible -- no-one in the world has beaten them.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Spy Chameleon is an incredibly fun game, and one that should definitely be picked up. While I typically advocate going for games when they're on special, the price for Spy Chameleon is already cheap as chips for the content delivered. I'd actually recommend paying full price for it so that the developers are able to work on a sequel sooner! :)

review:
[h1]Spy Chameleon est un excellent jeu d’infiltration[/h1]

Il faut l’admettre, il n’y a rien à critiquer sur ce jeu. Il est tout simplement excellent. C’est d’ailleurs pour ça que tout le monde en dit du bien.

Vous jouez un caméléon qui s’est spécialisé dans l’espionnage. Il dérobe des documents, prend des photos compromettantes, etc. Pour cela, notre gentil caméléon pénètre dans les maisons et doit éviter les systèmes de protection, les robots, les caméras et les animaux domestiques. Son avantage, il peut changer de couleur et se dissimuler ici ou là dans les maisons qu’ils visitent. Attention, toutefois a ne pas toucher qui que ce soit !

Le jeu propose un total de 75 niveaux (maisons à visiter) répartis à travers 5 missions.

Enfin, le prix est vraiment très abordable puisque le jeu est à moins de 5 euros.  C’est bête de vous priver d’un aussi bon jeu !

author: {'steamid': '76561198025065576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1688797092}
review:
Spy Chameleon - RGB Agent is stealthy in much the same way taking a sack full of hammers to the face is stealthy; while the perpetrator announces his assault beforehand with a vuvuzela blast.  That is to say, it's not stealthy at all. 

Wow, that's a pretty rough opener for a supposed stealth game, eh?  But you'll notice I still gave this one a thumbs up.

To continue my metaphor, the stitching on the bag was just exquisite, the sound of the hammers crashing together was a tour de force, and the bits of my skull moved in ways that frankly astounded medical experts.  Fortunately, I am the kind of guy who can appreciate these things.  Though I'd have appreciated them more if they'd happened to somebody else.

You see, as the living, breathing reason banks feel compelled to keep their pens attached to chains, I think of myself as something of an expert on stealth games.  There's nothing I love more than stealth done right in video games.  But what is a stealth game and why doesn't Spy Chameleon qualify?  

Well, a stealth game has you move through an area, usually attempting to accomplish some objective (say, take everything not nailed down) and leave without being seen.  There's a danger of being caught and that requires some intelligence on the part of the challenges standing between you and your objectives.  For a game to be a stealth game, it needs reactive enemies, otherwise it's just an obstacle course.  And that's what Spy Chameleon is: a time trial, obstacle course, collect-a-thon game.

Yes, it has the trappings of stealth.  You play as the titular chameleon spy, you are told briefly that your goal is to steal a thing and shown a picture of the thing at the end of several levels, and the obstacles take the form of "enemies" with vision cones.  But everything moves in perfect clockwork without reaction to your presence.  Changing your color to "hide" is just another form of dodging a static obstacle.  

You'll notice stealth is even a Steam user tag.  The devs themselves describe Spy Chameleon as: "a challenging arcade-puzzle game where the player needs to avoid being spotted thanks to the color-changing mechanisms of the main character."

So, yeah, Spy Chameleon fails as a stealth game.  But, now that that bone has been picked, if we judge it as an "arcade-puzzle game" or by my own moniker, "run-aroundy, collecty, obstacle torture time," then Spy Chameleon is an excellent example of its kind.  Personally, I couldn't stand playing it, since I don't much care for time trial obstacle courses that play to my OCD desires to collect all the bits.  But I have to admit, there's a Rube-Goldberg machine-like complexity to the levels and the timing required to solve them that makes them satisfying to complete.

Like the sack of hammers, it's fundamentally solid in its design and its presentation is surprisingly nice.  Spy Chameleon's soundtrack makes up for the game's lack of true infiltration by seeping it's bassy post-modern jazz into that part of your brain designed for looping catchy tunes.  And thanks to the artists, my favorite part of the game was failing the levels (which is good because I failed a lot).

Each failure shows you an image of the hazard that caught you: giant staring gold fish, trash-can robots spewing bold japanese writing, and the spy chameleon with a look of soul-wrenching embarassment for being caught about his naughty voyeuristic business.  The art assets manage to convey a ton of character, and - as you'd expect for a game called RGB Agent - it's all in bright eye-catching primaries.  Even the rather thematically dull environments: lab, office, storage rooms; are bright and good looking.

It's just a shame the art designer's theory seems to stop at the visuals.  The game looks like it has a ton of character.  Even the very premise that we're specifically playing a chameleon who is a spy is appealing.  But it never really goes anywhere with it.  There's no narrative to speak of.  

Oh, you're told that you're trying to get a photo of some celebrity with their paramour or steal a work of art, but you just run 15 levels of obstacles and then see a picture of the thing you got.  I'm not necessarily asking for War and Peace, or even any dialogue or text, but it feels like an opportunity was missed to tie all the whimsical characters together into some sort of cohesive story.  That might have gotten me to love the game despite not enjoying the gameplay.

And to better explain the gameplay:  You control the chameleon from a top down view and you navigate a room full of hazards: field-of-view cones attached to enemies that move in a set pattern.  If you touch a cone, you lose.  In addition to just dodging the cones as they move, you can stand against colored objects in the background and not be "seen."  Naturally, you've got the primary colors and the chameleon's natural green (i.e. 360 controller colors).  Along the way you collect flies and ladybugs strewn about the level for points and to unlock more levels.  You are, of course, challenged to beat a certain time.  There are a few variations to these basic mechanics: switches to open doors, movable obstacles to block vision cones, etc.  It is best to think about the levels as a puzzle, where the solution is where you move and finding the proper timing.

The game has a sort of phone-game sensibility to it.  You play a series of very short levels and get ranked at the end of them.  It's clearly not a mobile port.  It just has that arrangement.

It's mostly flawless in its implementation.  The only mechanical problem is that the chameleon's model obscures the parts of his body that are vulnerable to being seen.  Only the trunk of his body seems to trigger a failure and his bulbous head and tail make it hard to see the exact point you can safely stand.

That might seem a fussy complaint, but Spy Chameleon is a harsh time-trial collection hell.  The difference between you getting your lovely leaderboard/completionist cheese and a big fat shock for losers in this particular rat maze is literally measured in thousandths of a second. Well, okay, it is measured in that, but just getting through will probably require you to operate on the scale of hundredths of a second.  

No big deal for you speed-run, obstacle course aficionados, I'm sure.

That does lead to my other complaint.  I found there's not really a good balance for the difficulty.  It's a minor complaint since the game includes an easier mode and you can even skip levels that are giving you trouble, but it still stands.  On the "normal" difficutly I found the game to be a really boring exercise in just going from point A to point B.  Like connect-the-dots in full, glorious 3D.  

On hard, though, (which is the only difficulty that counts according to the game and its lusty achievements) I found the timing to be just outside of human reaction speed at points and my success was basically a matter of luck and treating my controller in a manner that would no doubt have it taken away from me by the authorities if they only knew.

And that's Spy Chameleon:  terrible stealth game.  Good speed-run, puzzle, collection thing.

I suppose it's been mislabeled since there aren't a lot of games that marry stealth and speed well and somebody's gonna want that.  The only one I can think of is The Marvelous Miss Take (which looks a bit like Spy Chameleon, actually).  If you want stealth and speed, play that.  But don't overlook Spy Chameleon because it doesn't do stealth.  Just be sure you're the kind of person that enjoys a sack of hammers to the face.

Er, "challenging arcade-puzzle" game.

review:
Very disappointing; a nice idea with polished presentation, and as such when you first start it seems like there is real potential for a solid game - but it quickly falls to pieces.

Once you pick up the basics it becomes unsatisfyingly rudimentary to blaze through all of the early levels. You will have to repeat each of them if you're inclined towards completing all the challenges, but far from feeling like this adds value to the game, it comes across as padding, and simply makes the gameplay feel old all the sooner.

Then, when you hit the more challenging levels, the real problem arises. The difficulty is never increased by clever use of the game mechanics, but rather without exception is created by the imprecision of the controls and the lack of clarity in the visual style.

It is incredibly frustrating to be forced to restart again and again because you were a few pixels off the precise spot the game determines safe, or because you moved a fraction of a second off when the game wanted you to move. As a result, when you finally beat a challenging level, rarely is there the feeling that your skill has prevailed at last. I wouldn't even say there was a genuine feeling of satisfaction - nothing more than a relief that you don't have to restart the level yet again, having hit the exact sequence of key presses the game demands of you.

It requires such a robotic approach, and such repetition, that despite only having a few hours of content it manages to become crushingly tiresome before it's done. Despite costing little, there's dozens of better games on steam at half the price.

Don't bother.

review:
Ked vyrastiem, budem chameleónom!

Rozhodne áno. Výborná, dalo by sa povedať logická, hra, kde sa chameleón musí dostať z jednej strany miestnosti na druhú. Bránia mu v tom rôzni roboti, kamery a rôzne živočíchy ako napríklad zmutované myši, muchy a rybičky. Akonáhle sa chameleón ocitne v Cone of View niektorého protivníka, je koniec a treba začať znova.
Hra obsahuje 3 challange - časový limit na miestnosť, vyzbieranie múch a lienok. Každý celok je ukončený akože záverečným bossom, čo je ale iba ďalšia miestnosť. 
Na 100% achievementy musí človek poriadne zamakať a to hlavne pre Sprintera, najťažšie z celeh hry, kedy je nutné všetky miestnosti prejsť pod úctihodných 18 minút.
A aby som nezabudol, určite je lepšie hrať s gamepadom ako na klávesnici, jednoduchšie sa dajú dosiahnúť lepšie časy.

review: Not a bad game at all. Cute little setting and playing a chameleon that changes color to surroundings is a good idea. Not really any story though. The game can be finished in about 1.5 hours, so SUPER short. The idea of avoiding searchlights and cameras is basically the entire premise and you do that for 75 levels, so a little more variety would have helped. That being say, the game does a good job of providing new mechanics and obstacles to get around. There were a few problems. The switching colors from 2 different colors next to each other while running could not be worse. You have to time it perfectly or you don't get spotted, and even then it usually doesn't work. I would sit there pressing it right before, right during, and right after I would get into the new color and none of them would work. Then randomly 1 time it would work for some reason, then the next 10 wouldn't, showing a lot of inconsistency. That was a huge design error and can be quite frustrating, that should have been made smoother and more intuitive. The other mistake was with the use of the box. Although it's cool in idea, I was using a ps3 controller with ds3/better ds3 tool, and every time I would stop it would say I was moving and I would get caught, even if my guy was stopped. This was fixed by using the keyboard, but still even though part of it may have been the software of the tool, I would not be moving and I would still get caught. So that was another annoying thing. All in all it's still a fun game. 7/10

review:
Très belle petite surprise que ce petit jeu. Vous incarnez un caméléon agent secret dont le but est de prendre des photos compromettantes, voler une recette, traquer un gros rat... Pour se faire, il vous faudra toute votre habileté pour défier les 75 niveaux du jeu et éviter poissons, rats, robots, caméra, mouches géantes... Votre arme principale ? Comme tout bon caméléon, vous pouvez alterner entre 4 couleurs afin de vous fondre dans le paysage (Sur des tapis, des pots de peintures, des taches au sol). Mais ce n'est pas tout, à votre disposition également, des boites en carton (pour vous y cacher), des armoires à déplacer afin de vous libérer un accès, des machines arrêtant les mouvements.... 
Pour finir, restez bien accroché et concentré. Si le jeu n'est pas si dur une fois la mécanique comprise, certains succès (les 3 coccinelles en 17.5s ou le niveau 50 a faire sans changer de couleur) ou niveaux ne manqueront pas de vous faire pêter un cable !!! Très chaude recommandation pour ma part et vivement la suite (D'ores et déjà en préparation) MIAM !!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066679847', 'num_games_owned': 1448, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 191, 'last_played': 1423730779}
review:
または!

非常にキュートでポップなキャラクターを操り潜入するステルス系のゲームです。

可愛らしいキャラクターに反して厳密な操作が多く求められる、ステージの終盤の所では心が折れてしまうほどの難易度です。

難易度は高く、判定がシビアでほんの少し判定をかすった程度で即アウトになります。本当にシビアです。

ゲームのプレイに関してはほとんどといって良いほど言語を使わない丁寧な作りとなっており、簡単な英語くらいしかゲーム内には使われておらず英語アレルギーの方にもお勧め出来ます。

キャラクターの細かな動作が可愛らしく、本ゲームの主人公のモチーフであるカメレオンの特徴を活かしていると思います。
ちょっとキャラクター自体が日本的でない海外っぽいキャラクターですがそれで毛嫌いするにはちょっと勿体ないほどの作品です。

悪い所をあげると色の変化をする際の色の配置の作り込みが若干甘い気がしました、無駄に複雑にしパターンが読みにくくさせる方向での難易度の上昇のさせ方はちょっとプレイしにくいなと感じました。

私はキーボードでプレイをしなぜUIOPのキー操作で色が変わるのかよく分らないままプレイをしましたが、他の外国の方のレビューを見て解りました、この色はXBOX標準のボタンのカラーなんですね。

そういった意味ではキーボードよりも直感的に理解できるコントローラの利用もお勧めします。

author: {'steamid': '76561198015153950', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1423586508}
review:
Fantástico videojuego de infiltración y sigilo donde el objetivo es llegar de un punto A a un punto B sin ser detectado por los radares.

Eres un camaleón y en cada nivel hay 3 objetivos, comer todas las moscas del nivel, una vez cumples este objetivo se desbloquea el de comer todas las mariquitas y finalmente está el objetivo de pasarte el nivel en un tiempo determinado, esto último está muy bien ya que hay marcadores mundiales donde queda registrada tu marca con la del resto de jugadores.

El camaleón tiene la habilidad de cambiar entre 4 colores: verde, azul, rojo y amarillo para evitar ser detectado, conforme vas avanzando niveles hay otras formas de ocultarte.

El juego tiene 75 niveles pudiendo elegir entre pasarlos en modo normal o modo difícil, personalmente recomiendo este último por suponer un mayor reto y poder obtener la recompensa de todos los logros que tiene el juego.

Completarlo al 100% puede llevar unas 9/10 horas pero si no eres completista puedes acabarlo antes.

Juego muy divertido e ideal para partidas cortas en las que no tienes mucho tiempo para estar jugando.

Recomendable 100%

author: {'steamid': '76561198089808499', 'num_games_owned': 497, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 676, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 676, 'last_played': 1429339267}
review:
Spy Chameleon - RGB Agent is a fun, unique and charming indie game for fans of stealth and puzzle games.

It a fairly short, but challenging game. I completed the game with 29/30 achievements in a little over 11 hours. It can be difficult and will have you raging at times, but it's very enjoyable. There are some indie games that are so challenging, you feel like the developers hate you and just want you to suffer. However, this game is difficult enough to make you feel challenged without making you feel like completing it is an impossible task. 

There is no story. It's just 75 levels of pure gameplay. In addition to the 75 levels, each one has 3 corresponding challenges to complete. There's collect all flies, collect all ladybugs and beat the time. This gives each level replayability. I was surprised at how innovative the game felt. As you progressed through the game, the levels not only became harder and more complex, but they added things into the environment that added advantages and disadvantages. There's colored surfaces to help you blend in, button-triggered moving walls to hide behind, boxes to hide in, etc.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
This game is worth checking out if you're a fan of stealth games or puzzle games and is definitely worth the $5 it's priced at. There is no story. So if you need a plot to enjoy a game, this game doesn't have it. But if you just want a moderately challenging puzzle game, this is a good one.

review:
[b]Spy Chameleon - RGB Agent[/b] brings a nice and innovative idea that will keep you entertained for a while. 
Unfortunately, as with many other indie games, RGB Agent suffers from the developer's inability to balance the game's difficulty. 
There is a "normal" and a "hard" mode, but the normal difficulty is already turned up to eleven. 

To name the major annoyances:
- Security cameras are able to see you [b]everywhere[/b] in the level, whether it makes sense or not. 
- The security robots are moving way too fast for your chameleon. There is a "turbo" button, but it doesn't make much of a difference.
- The default controls don't make a whole bunch of sense and [b]CANNOT[/b] be changed. How is this acceptable by today's standards is beyond me O.o
- You don't have to have a controller to play this game, but if you do have one, it's going to make your life much easier.
The keyboard controls are out of question and the mouse tends to get "stuck" when it leaves the boundaries of the level, which is a serious problem. 


Now I'm not saying that RGB Agent is a terrible game. It's not.
What I'm saying is, if you prefer forgiving games with well balanced difficulty, RGB Agent might not be your cup of tea ;)

review:
변장의 달인, 카멜레온 스파이 게임.
그리고 작은 인디게임의 저력을 보여준 훌륭한 게임.

전형적인 순수 잠입 게임이다. 전투는 없으며 시야에 들키거나 적들과 부딪히는 순간 리타이어. 순수히 적들의 시야를 피하는 것만 가능하다. 그래도 카멜레온이 주인공이니만큼 자신의 특기인 "몸 색깔 변화"를 통해 주변 색상과 같은 색으로 변장하여 숨을 수 있다는 점은 충분히 참신하다. 카멜레온이라는 특성도 잘 살렸고.

총 75개의 스테이지가 있다. 짧다면 짧고, 길다면 길다고 할 수 있겠는데, 인디 게임 치고는 그래도 제법 괜찮은 볼륨이다. 난이도는 별로 어렵지 않다. 그리고 플레이어의 손을 별로 타지 않는다. 손보단 눈으로, 그리고 머리로 풀어나가는 잠입 게임. 급하게 생각하지 말고 지긋이 스테이지를 보면 시야가 빈 곳이 눈에 띌 것이고, 어떻게 플레이해야 할 지 어렵지 않게 판단이 설 것이다. 그렇게 느긋이 미션 하나하나 풀어나가는 재미가 있는 게임.

단, 적들의 움직임이 2배 빨라지고, 일부 도전과제가 걸려있는 하드 모드로 들어가면 이야기가 살짝 달라진다. 쉬운 컨트롤에 머리만 살짝 굴리면 되는 게임에서, 손도 눈도 뇌도 바빠지는 게임으로 돌변해버린다. 1mm의 판정이 아쉬워지고, 0.04초가 아쉬워지고, 정신없이 움직이는 적들과 시야가 무서워진다. 라이트 유저라면 가급적이면 접근하지 말길 바라며, 혹여나 본인처럼 모든 것을 불태울 자신이 있는 자라면...... 그대의 무모함에 가까운 근성과 용기에 경의를 표하도록 하겠다.

어쨌거나 재미있는 게임이다. 그리고 생각보다 굉장히 알찬 게임이다. 가볍게 즐기기에도, 도전과제 사냥하기에도. 스피드런 도전으로도, (그리고 깨알같은 카드 농사 용도로도) 어느 구석으로 봐도 정말 괜찮은 게임이다.

review:
Spy Chameleon is a cheap and fun puzzle-stealth to play. The look is vibrant and fun, the difficulty scales fairly, and the controls are straight-forward. Although you have to be careful to not be a loosey goosey with moving, because you can easily waltz right into being spotted. For example: there are paint buckets you can knock over to have on-the-spot blending in, but the "hitbox" of the paint spatters are relatively small and you can easily mess up (no pun intended) because of it. And while I don't play with a game controller, I imagine having color-coordinated buttons to change color would be better than the horizontal key changes. 

Overall, if you're on any kind of extended break from university or work and have time to spare, it's great fun.

review:
I really liked this game! It is a mixture of puzzle and hardcore-ish execution based game of "trial and error" and mild mindfuck thrown here and there.

The premise is original and the gameplay is simple and feels polished. The controls works great. It is somehow challenging to some people for what I have read, but you should be able to plow through it in around 4 to 6 hours. My most favorite part by far is the Time challenge mode, where you will be ranked both globally and against your friends. It is fun to figure out ways to improve your time, and the level design in most levels is geared towards that goal. The same can be said for the additional ladybug and flies challenges, where you may have to take special detours and sort extra hurdles... I am not a big achievement guy, but they're there and they add to the replayability.

All in all, a very nice game with some ingenious level designs, cool music and overall a fun experience. Give it a try!

review:
A gamepad is absolutely a must for this game. 360-degree controls are nice, but moreover, certain missions (for instance, the final mission of the first set) almost require you to move diagonally while also switching colors, which requires three keyboard inputs. Due to how keyboards are designed (google "keyboard rollover" for details), three simultaneous inputs aren't always recognized. 

The UIOP keys (used for color switching) aren't typically used often in games, so even specially-designed "gamer keyboards" may have problems with this (most prioritize isolating circuits on the left side for WASD-area movement). 

If it was possible to rebind keys this wouldn't be an issue, but the developers - for whatever reason - have not implemented this option. UIOP is pretty weird to begin with, and even without key jamming I'd probably prefer them on 1234.

(to test your keyboard, google "Keyboard Ghosting Explained" and click the first link from Microsoft)

Ignoring this pretty major issue, the game is a fun little timewaster - nothing too complex, but (again, aside from the above problem) competently executed. But as it stands I can't give this game a thumbs up - we're nearly two decades into the 21st century, if you design a PC game, there's honestly no excuse for not allowing players to set their own controls.

review: Очень красиво нарисованная, с приятным саундтреком, головоломка. Мы играем за хамелеона-вора, которые может менять свой цвет (внезапно!), тем самым сливаясь с цветом окружающей обстановки и пропадая из поля зрения сторожевых ботов/камер. На первый взгляд, все очень красиво, опрятно, да и геймплей в принципе неплох. Всего в игре 5 заданий по 15 уровней с челенджами разного уровня сложности. Но пройдя 1 заданий, мне стало понятно, что интереса играть в эту игру уже нет. Уровни однообразные. Идем от старта к финишу, не попадая в поле зрения ботов/камер и попутно (если хочется) собираем жуков. И так все уровни. Во втором задании еще появились закрытые двери и ключи к ним, которые нужно сначала достать. Но интересней играть от этого не стало. Любителям головоломок, да и просто красивых игр рекомендую, но скорее всего ничего нового и увлекательно в игре вы не найдете.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022820771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 269, 'last_played': 1407108124}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IqnlHalBETY&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA
Spy Chameleon- RGB Agent, going into this you have to have the mind set of a time runner, and leader board player. The game is devised up into many different levels and a large amount unlock to you as you progress so you don't get wall stuck on just one mission. As you progress through the nicely designed levels the game gets much harder. The game does have stealth, and in the earlier missions it is of heavy use, done right with the ability to change into four colors in order to blend into your background, red, blue, green, teal. Sadly there is no color blind option in the menu. 

The issues come from as you progress through the levels, the game turns into less of a stealth based, and more of a time runner. Even through the clock runs up not down, every movement has to be perfect, ever time carried out flawless or else you will set off an alarm and be sent back. This is good for people who want a hard time runner, leader board challenge, but for the rest of us it kills the desire to play again. The game is not bad for what it does it does right, but its not so easy, and can get annoying very fast. 

So if you don't enjoy bashing your head for the fastest time, or improving your own score against your self then this will not be for you. The stealth does not carry its self alone and is traded out for speed and perfect click timing on later missions. Thanks for your time and viewership, for more reviews be sure to check out the channel here http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

author: {'steamid': '76561198050634317', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1404982860}
review:
Hra určitě zaujme tím, že přináší nový herní prvek do takových her. Jako chameleon pro vás bude totiž nutné měnit svou barvu (celkem jsou čtyři barvy) před zraky nepřátel.
Hra má 75 krátkých levelů, z toho připadá každých 15 na trochu jiné prostředí (sklepy, kanceláře...). Vždy máte za úkol dojít z bodu A do bodu B, ale cestu znepříjemňují protivníci. Těch je taky více druhů, a tak se vás snaží odhalit roboti, kamery, krysy nebo ryby v avkárku. Přičemž každý "nepřítel" se chová odlišně a potkávat je budete postupně.
Pokud vás spatří, tak vás čeká restart daného levelu, nebo obnova na checkpointu (odhadem je jeden na jednu místnost). Jak restart, tak změna barvy je naštěstí téměř okamžitá, takže hra není frustrující, a vy tak klidně můžete bez obav opakovat a opakovat.
Splynout s prostředím můžete např. když převrhnete kýbl s barvou, jinak pro splynutí slouží barevné koberce, které jsou po místnosti různě rozmístěné.

Úrovně jsou vybalancované. Někdy jsou akční, jindy zase logické (posunování věcí). Řekl bych tak půl na půl možná, a to je dobře. Čím jste ve hře dále, tím je samozřejmě těžší a těžší; a pak kombinuje jak akci, tak myšlení (které zase není nijak těžké, ale úplně to postačí pro změnu).
Ovládání na klávesnici je naštěstí bezproblémové a snadné. Šipky pro pohyb a 4 klávesy na zbarvení. Chodit se dá i myší, ale s tou jsem měl hrozné problémy, kdy jsem se najednou zastavoval.

Výzvy hry jsou tady důležité, jako snad nikde jinde. Pokud je nebudete plnit, hrou prosvištíte ani ne za poloviční čas (mě trvalo na 100% přes 8 hodin). Výzvy jsou hned tři, a to: dokončit místnost do určitého času, sebrat všechny mouchy a berušky. Díky toho budete rádi hrát úroveň znova (a snažit se čas stáhnout ještě o těch pár vteřin).
Vyzdvihnout ještě musím krásný výtvarný styl a cenu (která je kvůli kurzu euro k dolaru 1:1 na stránkách vývojářů ještě levnější. Ze stránek navíc dostanete jak DRM free, tak Steam kopii hry, takže hru kupte tam).
Škoda že hra nemá svůj vlastní editor misí, který by hře prodloužil životnost, ale už tak je tady hodně zábavy za málo peněz.

review: So I wandered through the indie section on the summer sale and I found Spy Chameleon on sale for maybe $2. I shrugged, thought "What the hell," and added it to my cart. The game's concept, get to the goal without being spotted, is not only easy to grasp but is challenging at the same time. It brings all the challenge of speeding through a level to get the best possible time and adds stealth to it in the form of changing colors. YES. Totally original, totally killin' soundtrack! Reccommended to anyone who likes stealth games and original concepts in a gaming market filled with sequels, prequels, and DLC.

review:
Fun, beautiful, and challenging game. The art style is perfect for the game design and the rooms look amazing. I read that some people found movement using a gamepad slower, but I used a X360 controller and the movement speed was the same as using a mouse. (Possibly updated since those comments). For me, using the controller was better because the colour change buttons were easier to remember and push.

As a stealth game, the gameplay is the same through out the game, you hide from enemies (sometimes for several seconds), eat flies, push stuff and try to make your way out the other door. For some people this may seem boring, but I found the different enemies, level design and strategies to get past enemies, made me want to keep playing this game (that and the achievements).

The enemies are great, they're so cute and deadly at the same time. The death/capture animation can be skipped by push of a button as soon as it starts and the level resets. Death/capture happens often.

review:
I really wanted to like this game and it starts well enough, but about 1.5 hours in it devolves into asshole level design requiring pixel perfect movement (which is insane in a game with analog movement). At first this is mitigated by the quick restarts and frequent checkpoints so when you die you rarely lose more than 10 seconds.

But the design only gets more dickish, in the end I spent 20 minutes on a single checkpoint that required pixel perfect, perfectly timed movement to simultaneously dodge 3 camera bots while pushing a block that was your only source of cover. You have to run around this crate pushing it an inch at a time before you run back to cover about 10 times in a row to complete the checkpoint and get caught on one corner for a fraction of a second and you're dead. That is not my idea of fun, I think it is tradgic that such a solid premiss with such a polished and inventive implementation can end up being so painful to play because the level designer didn't know when to quit.

Only buy this if you are okay only playing the game for 1.5 hours and then never seeing the ending (or if you are a masochist, that's when the fun begins.)

Awesome game! I hardly ever go for indie titles or casual games, but this one is a total anomaly! With damn near infinite replay value thanks to the fly/time/ladybug challenges plus a global leaderboard, this game has had me hooked since I picked it up 24 hours ago.

Spy Chameleon has one of the best learning curves I've ever experienced in a game - many levels are made in a way that is easy enough to complete, but difficult to master, especially in the later stages. The difficulty very gradually goes up, to the point where you don't even really realize that it's getting more difficult until you're trying to break the world record and you fail 50 times.

The main mechanic of the game isn't introduced all in the first 5 or 10 stages, which I believe is an extremely strong point. It gradually introduces new mechanics over each mission of 15 levels, so you aren't bombarded with new gimmicks but learn exactly how each new obstacle works and how it can be overcome.

Spy Chameleon is one of the best games I've played in quite a while. It stand out in my mind for being so different, while pretty much nailing the difficulty curve and keeping the player interested. I very much recommend this game to everybody, easily worth the price!

review:
My first thought was that this looked like a mobile port of some kind, but it is not!  

It's a stealth-based arcadey puzzle game where you have to reach an exit (by passing robot guards) without getting caught.  Alternate goals are available in each level (time limit, and get certain collectibles)

It's got a fun gimmick where you have to change colors (they correlate to the button colors on a 360 gamepad) to blend in with the surroundings, which makes the guards not see you.

It's actually really decent, and I'd say it's worth it for the price.

review:
Cool game!

The colour change mechanics are well thought, easy to learn and nicely distributed across levels, which creates some very interesting puzzles (I've enjoyed how the progressive addition of new features prevents it from becoming too repetitive, too). Also, the extended mission goals (find the ladybugs, speed run,...) help to add some challenge for completionists and definitely enhance replayability. In some levels the additional goals may create some frustration as they rely heavily on timing and/or location, but since you clearly feel how you get better with each try until you eventually reach the solution to those harder puzzles, that actually encourages you to keep playing. I admit that this is a matter of personal preference, but so far with me it's worked that way.

Even though gameplay is the strongest point for me, visuals work nicely, too, I love the chameleon design. Oh, and the "mission fail" screens are hilarious  :D
